qas.question: What is the explanation for copper's capacity for electrical conductivity?
What metal has a higher thermal conductivity than copper?
What is the maximum premissible current density in open air of copper?
What occurs when copper is placed touching another metal?
What happens to copper if an electrical current gets too high?
What is the explanation for copper's capacity for nuclear conductivity?
What metal has an equal thermal conductivity to copper?
What is the only permissible current density in open air of copper?
What occurs when copper is placed apart from another metal?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The softness<b5_0/><a0_0/> of copper partly explains its high electrical conductivity (59.6×106 S/m) and thus also high thermal conductivity, which are the second highest (to <a1_0><b6_0>silver<b6_0/><a1_0/>) among pure metals at room temperature. This is because the resistivity to electron transport in metals at room temperature mostly originates from scattering of electrons on thermal vibrations of the lattice, which are relatively weak for a soft metal. The maximum permissible current density of copper in open air is approximately <a2_0><b7_0>3.1×106 A/m2<b7_0/><a2_0/> of cross-sectional area, above which <a4_0>it begins to heat excessively<a4_0/>. As with other metals, if copper is placed against another metal, galvanic <a3_0><b8_0>corrosion<b8_0/><a3_0/> will occur.
